Notes: Cited primary age is that of the host Surprise Creek Formation (Jackson et al., 2005). Godsmark et al. (2017) indicate that "primary copper mineralisation is observed as early pre- to syn-diagenetic disseminations and various structural styles of mineralisation", so that it is possible that there are several periods of mineralisation and remobilisation, or that the mineralisation is epigenetic, in which case the inferred age is incorrect. Hence the age is given a low level of certainty. Endowment includes past production and resources as of 30 June 2017.

References: Green et al. (2014); Taheri and Bottrill (2004); Black et al. (2005); Green et al. (2014); ; Green et al. (2014)
Notes: Endowment includes pre-JORC mineral resource only (Green et al. 2014). The origin of this deposit is not well determined. Following Taheri and Bottrill (2004), it is interpreted as a (possibly) remobilised shale-hosted copper deposit, in which case the deposit would be of Mesoproterozoic or Neoproterozoic age. Alternatively, the deposit is genetically related to the Interview Granite, which has an age of 362.4 ± 1.9 Ma (Black et al., 2005). If this is true the granite age would be the best estimate of the age of mineralisation.

Texturally the base metal sulfides and associated pyrite overprint early syn-/diagenetic pyrite and marcasite, with even stratiform sphalerite filling intergranular porosity in the host siltstone. Marcasite also occurs late in the paragenetic sequence.

The molybdenite Re-Os ages cited are slightly older than, but within error of zircon U-Pb ages of the interpreted causative intrusions. Endowment includes production to June 2012 and mineral resources at 31 December 2016 attributed to "other" by Porter (2017f). The cited age of the second, overprinting mineralising event, which is interpreted as the main event, is the "most rigorous estimate" (McCuaig et al., 2001). This age does not assume a zero point. If a zero point is assumed, the isochron age is 2623 ± 26 Ma. The most precise individual molybdenite age is 2615 ± 9 Ma. All ages for the second event overlap with the 2612 ± 3 Ma (SHRIMP zircon U-Pb) age of the unmineralised Wourahming monzogranite. Endowment includes the sum of production to 2001 and 2009 resources prior to re-opening in a 2009 pre-mining resources estimate. Porter (2017a) cite a lower total metal endowment (e.g. 725 t Au) as he considered metal recoveries in making estimate.

(2013); Jagodzinski (2014); Apukhtina et al. (2017); Johnson and Cross (1995); Meffre et al. (2010); Ciobanu et al. (2013); Jagodzinski (2014); Apukhtina et al. (2017); Ehrig et al. (2017); http://portergeo.com.au/database/mineinfo.asp?mineid=mn001 (accessed January 2023)
Notes: The cited age is a uraninite age from Olympic Dam-like alteration at depth in the Roxby Downs Granite (Apukhtina et al., 2017). The age overlaps the age of the host Roxby Downs Granite (1593.5 ± 1.2 Ma: zircon SHRIMP U-Pb; Jagodzinski, 2014) and is supported by an age of 1584 ± 20 Ma from a felsic volcanic rock interpreted to be a peperite intruded into the mineralised breccias at Olympic Dam (Johnson and Cross, 1995) and a U-Pb and Pb-Pb ages of hematite of 1592 ± 15 Ma, 1590 ± 8 Ma and 1577 ± 5 ma (Ciobanu et al., 2013; Apukhtina et al., 2017). The cited ages are in contrast to much younger ages of ~1400 Ma to ~1200 Ma proposed by Meffre et al. (2010) based on pyrite Pb data. It is likely that significant disturbance or remobilisation has effect the ores post deposition. Endowment includes production of 3.8 Mt Cu, 0.53 kt (17 Moz) Ag, 59.1 t (1.9 Moz) Au and 81 kt U3O8 and total mineral resources at 30 June 2016 of 10,400 Mt at 0.77% Cu, 250 ppm U3O8, 1 g/t Ag and 0.32 gt Au (Ehrig et al., 2017). The lanthanide oxide grades were determined using La and Ce grades of 0.17% and 0.25%, respectively (http://portergeo.com.au/database/mineinfo.asp?mineid=mn001; accessed January 2023), and unweighted averages of La/Ce for ore types with over 0.3% Cu as tabulated in Ehrig et al. (2017). The estimated La grades were then converted to La oxide grades. The endowment of the lanthanides were estimated using the total mineral resource at 30 June 2016 and do not contain lanthanides contained in production prior to that date. It must be stressed here that the estimated grades for individual lanthanides are approximate and NOT code-compliant.

References: https://www.mindat.org/loc-18798.html (accessed March 2024); Walshe et al. (1981); Manning (1990); Raymond (1992); Huston and Kamprad (2001); Corbett (2014); Seymour et al. (2006); Denwer et al. (2017b); D Huston (unpublished data); Seymour et al. (2006); Denwer et al. (2017b)
Notes: Location is as that of the Prince Lyell orebody, the largest deposit in the district. The district extends 4 km north-south and 2 km east-west, with Prince Lyell in the southwest part of the district. Ore formation in the Mount Lyell field appears to have occurred during four events, three of which are Cu-Au-dominant, and the fourth Zn-Pb dominant (see Tasman/Crown Lyell). The earliest event, at ~500 Ma involved deposition of massive sulfide lenses (e.g. The Blow and South Lyell) and disseminated pyrite-chalcopyrite lenses (e.g. Prince Lyell) during volcanism. The second event, at ~491 Ma, involved the overprinting of the syn-volcanic ores by high sulfidation epithermal bornite-rich ores (e.g. North Lyell), and the third event involved the formation of paleo-gossan and related supergene deposits (e.g. King Lyell). The timing of formation of gossans and supergene zones may have occurred as far back as the Ordovician and there is some evidence of active formation (Corbett, 2014). Endowment includes pre-mining resources (311 Mt 0.97% Cu and 0.31 g/t Au: Seymour et al., 2006) for deposits discovered before 2005 and mineral resources for the Chert deposit (4.3 Mt at 1.5% Cu and 0.79 g/t Au: Denwer et al., 2017b), which was discovered in 2011.

Notes: The cited age is that of the host Mount Warner Volcanics, which, based on faunal assemblages have an Eifelian (Middle Devonian: 393.3-387.7 Ma). This age assumes a volcanic-hosted massive sulfide origin (e.g. Taube, 1986, 1990a) and is slightly older that the Mount Morgan Trondhjemite (379.9 ± 4.3 Ma: Donchak et al., 2013), which intrudes and contact metamorphoses the host volcanic succession. Alternatively, the deposit is an intrusion-related gold deposit associated with the Mount Morgan Trondhjemite (e.g. Sillitoe and Arnold, 1989). Endowment includes production only. Current tailings resource of 37.18 Mt grading 0.71 g/t Au, 0.09% Cu and 1.33 g/t Ag (Carbine Resources Limited, 2017) have not been included, and a mineral resource estimate for the Carpark and Slagheap Zn-rich ore lenses have not been determined.

Notes: Cited age of the Cambrian mineralisation is the middle of three statistically indistinguishable TIMS U-Pb ages (502.60 ± 0.93 Ma, 502.81 ± 0.98 Ma, 503.01 ± 0.97 Ma: Mortensen et al., 2015) from pumice breccia in the stratigraphic footwall of the deposit. Mn-rich carbonates closely associated with ore zones. Cambrian ore zones were overprinted by pyrrhotite- and magnetite-bearing assemblages during Devonian (the relative Fe-S-O mineral abundances are based on Cambrian mineralisation; for Devonian replacement, the relative abundances are po > py > mt >> hm). Trace pyrrhotite noted in Cu-rich zones outside of replaced zone and magnetite is minor to trace quantities in Zn-rich and pyritic zones. A granitic body has been inferred at 1 km depths at the southern end of the deposit based on gravity model. This granite, which forms part of the gravity ridge between the Heemskirk and Granite Tor batholiths, is inferred to be of similar age to the dated granites on this gravity Ridge (Heemskirk, Pine Hill and Granite Tor) at ~360 Ma (c.f. Black et al., 2005; Hong et al., 2017) and the source of the Devonian replacive mineralised zones.

The deposit occurs in two lodes parallel to the axis of the host Croydon Anticline (Marsden, 1979; Huston et al., 2000). Marsden (1979) interpreted the ore shoots to be remobilised from originally syn-genetic mineralisation into structurally favourable sites (e.g., fold hinge zones). Lead-rich gossan from the deposit yielded a Thorpe et al. (1992b) model age of 2869 Ma. The lead, however, has anomalously high μ, possibly indicating long-term U enrichment in the source, in which case this model age would be anomalously young. Alternatively, the deposit formed syn-tectonically. Endowment excludes minor Cu production of about 600 t (Marsden, 1979).

References: Ferguson (1999); Ferguson (1999); Huston et al. (2002a); Huston et al. (2002a)
Hussey et al. (2005); Hussey et al. (2005); Hussey et al. (2005)
Notes: Zircon U-Pb data define a unimodal population which is interpreted as closely approximating the depositional age of host volcaniclastic rocks.

References: https://portal.ga.gov.au; Leggo et al. (2019); Huston et al. (2020b); Cross et al. (2021); Savage (2020); Farias et al. (2022); Farias (2023); Cross et al. (2021); Farias et al. (2022); Farias (2023); Castile Resources Limited (2023)
Notes: Cited resources include mineral resources only. The resources cited in grade-tonnage data are of the zinc-rich zone only. Additional resources of 5.69 at 0.36% Cu that form in the rocks just above the unconformity with the Wiso Basin are not included in grade-tonnage data, but are included as total (copper) metal. Host unit is interpreted to be equivalent of Yungkulungu Formation owing to similarities in age and lithologies. The origin of the deposit is problematic. Savage (2020 interpreted the deposit as a shale-hosted zinc deposit akin to Mount Isa zinc or HYC. In contrast, Farias (2023) interpreted the deposit as a volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposit based on the association of mineralisation with felsic volcanic rocks and the presence of Cu-rich stringer-like mineralisation. LA-ICP-MS analyses of apatite from the Explorer 108 deposit yielded a lower intercept U-Pb age of 1724 ± 77 Ma, consistent with a similar age from the nearby Curiosity prospect, which yielded an age of 1740 ± 55 Ma (Farias et al., 2022a). These ages overlap with a Rb-Sr isochron age of hydrothermal biotite from Explorer 108 of 1783 ± 45 Ma (Farias et al., 2022b) and a 1729 ± 27 Ma maximum depositional age from the Explorer 108 ore host (Cross et al. (2021, 2022). Despite the large uncertainties, the geochronological and geological data are most consistent with a VHMS origin as proposed by Farias (2023), and the apatite lower intercept age is assigned as the most likely age of mineralisation.

Ametrano, Silvia, Etcheverry, Ricardo, Echeveste, Horacio, Godeas, Marta, and Zubia, Mario, 2000, VMS district of Tierra Del Fuego, Argentina, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 593–612.; Broili, Chris, Klohn, Mel, and Hodder, Robert, 2000, Exploration, geology, and mineral deposits of the Fin Del Mundo VMS project, Tierra Del Fuego, Argentina, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 567–591.; Logan, A.V., De Brodtkorb, M.K., and Schalamuk, I.B., 2000, Mineral deposits associated with submarine volcanism of Argentina, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 543–565.; Ricci, S.M., compiler, 1974, Territorio nacional de la Tierra Del Fuego, Antartdia E Islas Del Atlantico Sur: Ministerio de Economia, scale 1:750,000.; Servicio Geológico de la Dirección de Geología, 1950, Mapa geológico de la República Argentina: scale 1:2,500,000.;
Notes: Massive, disseminations, veinlets, small concordant lenses, 5 m long, 0.8 m thick, W end veinlets 12 m long. quartz-chalcopyrite-pyrite stockwork in 1 sq. km area.  pyrite-pyrrhotite-graphite disseminations ubiquitous.  Fault displaces deposit 300 m. Back arc marginal basin (calc alkaline to tholeiitic).

References: Logan, A.V., De Brodtkorb, M.K., and Schalamuk, I.B., 2000, Mineral deposits associated with submarine volcanism of Argentina, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 543–565.; Servicio Geológico de la Dirección de Geología, 1950, Mapa geológico de la República Argentina: scale 1:2,500,000.; Zappettini, E.O., and De Brodtkorb, M.K., 2000, The VMS Santa Elena deposit, San Juan Province, Argentina, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 613–616.
Notes: Oxide zone 25 m thick of hydrated ferric sulphates. Back arc ocean ridge basin or MORB. Production 0.5 million t @ 0.08% Cu, 3.3% Zn, 2.1% Pb, 4.2 g/t Au, 87 g/t Ag, reserves undetermined.

References: McKay, W.J., and Davies, R.H., 1990, Woodlawn—A synthesis of exploration and structural geology, in Glasson, K.R., and Rattigan, J.H., eds., Geological aspects of the discovery of some important mineral deposits in Australia: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph Series no. 17, p. 211–218.; Pogson, D.J., 1972, Geology of New South Wales:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales, scale 1:1,000,000.
Notes: Small lens, 70 m strike length, 300 m down-dip, 2-10 m thick, 5-200 m below surface, banded and breccia clast in chlorite matrix. Back arc rift basin (tholeiitic volcanism).

References: Felton, E.A., 1974, Goulburn: Geological Survey of New South Wales Metallogenic Map Series Sheet 51/55-12, scale 1:250,000.; McKay, W.J., and Davies, R.H., 1990, Woodlawn—A synthesis of exploration and structural geology, in Glasson, K.R., and Rattigan, J.H., eds., Geological aspects of the discovery of some important mineral deposits in Australia: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph Series no. 17, p. 211–218.; Pogson, D.J., 1972, Geology of New South Wales:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales, scale 1:1,000,000.
Notes: Vertical pipe-like body, 180 m below surface. S and Pb isotopes suggest epigenetic origin.

References: Fogarty, J.M., 1998, Girilambone district copper deposits, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 593–599.; Gilligan, L.B., and Byrnes, J.G., 1995, Metallogenic study and mineral deposit data sheets, Cobar metallogenic map 1:250,000:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales, 240 p.; Gilligan, L.B., Byrnes, J.G., Watkins, J.J., and Pogson, D.J., 1994, Cobar:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales Metallogenic Map Series Sheet SH/55-14, scale 1:250,000.; Smith, E.A., 1976, The cupriferous pyrite deposits of the Girilambone-Hermidale district, in  Gilligan, L.B., Markham, N.L., and Suppel, D.W., eds., Ore deposits of the Lachlan Fold Belt, New South Wales: Sydney, International Geological Congress, 25th, Excursion Guide 15C, p. 19–23.
Notes: Massive, dissemination, footwall stringers. 120 m strike length, 10 m width.

References: Ashley, P.M., and Wolfenden, B.J., 2004, Halls Peak massive sulphide deposits, New England, NSW: Cooperative Research Centre for Landscape Environments and Mineral Exploration, 2 p., http://crcleme.org.au/RegExpOre/HallsPeak.pdf (last accessed January 24, 2008).; Gilligan, L.B., Brownlow, J.W., Camerson, R.G., and Henley, H.F., 1992, Dorrigo-Coffs Harbour: Geological Survey of New South Wales Metallogenic Map, scale 1:250,000.; Gilligan, L.B., Brownlow, J.W., Camerson, R.G., and Henley, H.F., 1992, Metallogenic study and mineral deposit data sheets, Dorrigo-Coffs Harbour 1:250,000 metallogenic map: Geological Survey of New South Wales, 509 p.; Palethorpe, C., 1980, Khan’s Creek Cu-Pb-Zn prospect, Nambucca Block, N.S.W., in Butt, C.R.M., and Smith, R.E., eds., Conceptual models in exploration geochemistry: Journal of Geochemical Exploration, v. 12, no. 2/3, p. 320–321.; Pogson, D.J., 1972, Geology of New South Wales:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales, scale 1:1,000,000.
Notes: Massive lens, strike E-W, dips 60˚N sub-parallel to cleavage of slate. Gossan zone.

References: Fogarty, J.M., 1998, Girilambone district copper deposits, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 593–599.; Gilligan, L.B., Byrnes, J.G., Watkins, J.J., and Pogson, D.J., 1994, Cobar:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales Metallogenic Map Series Sheet SH/55-14, scale 1:250,000.;
Notes: Massive lens, 250 m strike length, 46 m width. Reserves 1.915 million t @ 1.04% Cu, open at depth.

References: Pogson, D.J., 1972, Geology of New South Wales:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales, scale 1:1,000,000.; Stevens, B., 1972, Bathurst: Geological Survey of New South Wales Metallogenic Map Series Sheet S1/55-8, scale 1:250,000.; Valliant, R.I., and Meares, R.M.D., 1998, Lewis Ponds gold-silver-copper-lead-zinc deposits, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 635–640.
Notes: Minimum tonnage 7.2 million t @ 0.12% Cu, 3.5% Zn, 1.73% Pb, 1.87 g/t Au, 95 g/t Ag. Massive, semi-massive, disseminated sulfide lenses, 1.3 km strike length, 200 m width.  Elongate zone of stringer Cu 2 km x 700 m. Main zone and Toms zone are at two separate stratigraphic levels. Main zone has 3 subparallel lenses, 300 m total strike length, 650 m down-plunge, open at depth. Central lens is 100 to 500 m below surface, averages 15 m in horizontal thickness. Hanging wall lens averages 4 m in horizontal thickness. Footwall lens averages 18 m in horizontal thickness, 150 to 500 m below surface. Toms zone is 900 m along strike from the Main zone. 250 m strike length, from the surface down to 500 m depth, averages 5 m horizontal thickness. Open in all directions. Footwall stringer is 2 km x 700 m in area of quartz-chlorite-chalcopyrite veins.

References: Fogarty, J.M., 1998, Girilambone district copper deposits, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 593–599.; Gilligan, L.B., and Byrnes, J.G., 1995, Metallogenic study and mineral deposit data sheets, Cobar metallogenic map 1:250,000:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales, 240 p.; Gilligan, L.B., Byrnes, J.G., Watkins, J.J., and Pogson, D.J., 1994, Cobar:  Sydney, Geological Survey New South Wales Metallogenic Map Series Sheet SH/55-14, scale 1:250,000.;
Notes: Massive, disseminations, lens, 300 m long, 14 m width. Reserves 2.465 million t @ 0.89% Cu, open at depth. Oxidation down to depths of 50 m.

References: Day, R.W., Whitaker, W.G., Murray, C.G., Wilson, I.H., and Grimes, K.G., 1983, Queensland geology, a companion volume to the 1:2,500,000 scale geological map (1975): Geological Survey of Queensland Publication 383, 194 p.; Gemmell, J.B., Large, R.R., and Zaw, Khin, 1998, Palaeozoic volcanic-hosted massive sulphide deposits: Australian Geological Survey Organisation Journal of Australian Geology and Geophysics, v. 17, no. 4, p. 129–137.; Huston, D.L., 1993, The effect of alteration and metamorphism on wall rocks to the Balcooma and Dry River South volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits, Queensland, Australia: Journal of Geochemical Exploration, v. 48, p. 277–307.; Huston, D.L., Taylor, Terry, Fabray, John, and Patterson, D.J., 1992, A comparison of the geology and mineralization of the Balcooma and Dry River South volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits, northern Queensland: Economic Geology, v. 87, p. 785–811.; Stolz, A.J., 1995, Geochemistry of the Mount Windsor Volcanics—Implications for the tectonic setting of Cambro-Ordovician volcanic-hosted massive sulfide mineralization in northeastern Australia: Economic Geology, v. 90, no. 5, p. 1080–1097.
Notes: Massive, semi-massive, disseminations in contact. Thin tabular body (1-10 m), N-S trending 1 km long, up to 200 m wide.

References: Beam, S.D., Laing, W.P., and O’Neill, D.M., 1993, The exploration history and geology of the polymetallic Reward deposit, Mt Windsor Volcanic Belt, north Queensland, in Henderson, R.A., ed., Guide to the economic geology of the Charters Towers region, northeastern Queensland: Queensland: Geological Society of Australia Field Excursion Guidebook, 1993 Field Conference, p. 81–91.; Day, R.W., Whitaker, W.G., Murray, C.G., Wilson, I.H., and Grimes, K.G., 1983, Queensland geology, a companion volume to the 1:2,500,000 scale geological map (1975): Geological Survey of Queensland Publication 383, 194 p.; Large, R.R., 1992, Australian volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits—Features, styles, and genetic models: Economic Geology, v. 87, no. 3, p. 471–510.
Notes: Pipe-like and small lenses, capped by Au-Ag rich gossan breccia, 100 m below surface, to 400 m depth, 75 m wide. Zn-Pb deposit is stratiform and separate from Cu-Au pipe.

References: Day, R.W., Whitaker, W.G., Murray, C.G., Wilson, I.H., and Grimes, K.G., 1983, Queensland geology, a companion volume to the 1:2,500,000 scale geological map (1975): Geological Survey of Queensland Publication 383, 194 p.; Huston, D.L., Taylor, Terry, Fabray, John, and Patterson, D.J., 1992, A comparison of the geology and mineralization of the Balcooma and Dry River South volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits, northern Queensland: Economic Geology, v. 87, no. 3, p. 785–811.; Rea, P.S., and Close, R.J., 1998, Surveyor 1 copper-lead-zinc-silver-gold deposit, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, p. 737–742.; Stolz, A.J., 1995, Geochemistry of the Mount Windsor Volcanics—Implications for the tectonic setting of Cambro-Ordovician volcanic-hosted massive sulfide mineralization in northeastern Australia: Economic Geology, v. 90, no. 5, p. 1080–1097.
Notes: Minimum tonnage: 0.971 million t @ 0.88% Cu, 12.3% Zn, 5.56% Pb, 0.95 g/t Au, 113.8 g/t Ag (open to the east). Semi-massive, stringer sulfides, synform, plunges 20˚S, 250 m strike length, 80 m wide, 23 m thick; Surveyor East is a supergene-oxide lens 200 m E of Surveyor 1, containing 50,000 t (no grades reported). Huston and others (1992) says lens was intersected in 1981.

Notes: Stratiform, massive, banded, one main lens gently pitching, down-faulted segment to west, smaller lenses to east; disseminated and stringer pyrite-chalcopyrite-sphalerite-galena, well-layered texture of sulfides and gangue, slump features, brecciation, replacement. Continental margin calc-alkaline affinity. Gossan present. East Thalanga, discovered in 1981,  has 0.177 million t 3.2% Cu, 7.1% Zn, 1.5% Pb, 65 g/t Ag, 0.9 g/t Au (Beam and others, 1993).

Notes: Pyrite-chalcopyrite-sphalerite-galena massive, pyrite-chalcopyrite dissemination, quartz-bornite and pyrite-chalcopyrite stringer. Orebodies: South Lyell, West Lyell, Royal, Tharsis, Comstock, Crown Lyell No. 1, Crown Lyell No. 2, Crown Lyell No. 3, North Lyell, Copper Clay, Cape Horn, Twelve West, Lyell Tharsis, Lyell Comstock, Blow, Tasman, Crown Lyell Extension, Crown Three. Tilting and erosion may have removed part of the deposit, which may explain the lack of lead and zinc deposits. Gossan present. Large alteration zone along a fault may have been a feeder zone for the mineralization. Extensional basin in an arc-continental collision zone.

References: Cochrane, G.W., 1982, Copper, lead, zinc and barium deposits of Victoria: Geological Survey of Victoria Bulletin 61, 166 p.; Large, R.R., 1992, Australian volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits—Features, styles, and genetic models: Economic Geology, v. 87, no. 3, p. 471–510.; Liu, S.F., and Bain, J.H.C., 2007, Heathcote Igneous Province: Commonwealth of Australia, web site, http://dbforms.ga.gov.au/pls/www/geodx.strat_units.matching_provs?fst=Y (last accessed September 18, 2007).; Weston, K.S., 1992, Minerals of Victoria: Geological Survey of Victoria Report 92, 68 p., map scale 1:1,000,000.; Williams, B., and Radojkovic, A.M., 2004, The regolith of the Ararat 1:100 000 map area: Department of Primary Industries, Victorian Initiative for Minerals and Petroleum Report 81. ; Willocks, A.J., 1999, Geophysical responses over the Mount Ararat prospect: Geological Survey of Victoria Report 119 and Australian Society of Exploration Geophysicists Special Publication 11.
Notes: Massive banded and disseminations in tholeiitic basalt. Consists of a basal boninitic lava sequence, overlain by a thick pile of low-K tholeiitic basalts with geochemical affinities to basalts associated with arc splitting in modern intra-oceanic arcs. Considered to have formed in the fore-arc region of an intra-oceanic arc in the Mid-Cambrian (ca 520-525 Ma?) and to have been emplaced as a massive ophiolite sheet westward onto a thin passive margin during arc-continental collision around 510 Ma. Overturned (stratigraphic sequence is corrected).

Notes: Massive, several lenses, interfingering, veins in structures, hanging wall disseminations, local stockwork beneath massive ore; upper Zn-rich zone, lower Cu-rich zone. Abundant magnetite. 1600 m long mineralized horizon, main lens 600 m long, 30 m thick. Gossan outcrop. Calc-alkaline volcanics in continental margin. Age based on zircon from felsic volcaniclastic unit at Gossan Hill.

References: Ashley, P.M., Dudley, R.J., Lesh, R.H., Marr, J.M., and Ryall, A.W., 1988, The Scuddles Cu-Zn prospect, an Archean volcanogenic massive sulfide deposit, Golden Grove District, Western Australia: Economic Geology, v. 83, no. 5, p. 918–951.; Barley, Mark, 1998, Archean volcanic-hosted massive sulphides: Australian Geological Survey Organisation Journal of Australian Geology and Geophysics, v. 17, no. 4, p. 69–73.; Bishop, J.R., and Lewis, R.J.G., 1992, Geophysical signatures of Australian volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits: Economic Geology, v. 87, no. 3, p. 913–920.; Large, R.R., 1992, Australian volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits—Features, styles, and genetic models: Economic Geology, v. 87, no. 3, p. 471–510.; Mill, J.H.A., 1990, The Scuddles base metal deposit—An exploration case history, in Glasson, K.R., and Rattigan, J.H., eds., Geological aspects of the discovery of some important mineral deposits in Australia: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph Series no. 17, p. 179–186.; Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.; Smith, R.E., and Perdrix, J.L., 1983, Pisolitic laterite geochemistry in the Golden Grove massive sulphide district, Western Australia: Journal of Geochemical Exploration, v. 18, p. 131–164.; Whitford, D.J., and Ashley, P.M., 1992, The Scuddles volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposit, Western Australia—Geochemistry of the host rocks and evaluation of lithogeochemistry for exploration: Economic Geology, v. 87, no. 3, p. 873–888.
Notes: Massive in two stratiform lenses (main and central), stringer zone in envelope of pyrite, 10-15 m thick below main lens, 5-7 m thick below central lens; 130-150 m below surface. Age based on zircon from felsic volcaniclastic unit at Gossan Hill. Resources 26.1 million t @ 1.2% Cu, 6.9% Zn, 0.5% Pb, 0.9 g/t Au, 59 g/t Ag, open at depth.

References: Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Parker, T.W.H., and Brown, T., 1990, Horseshoe gold-copper-silver deposit, in Hughes, F.E., ed., Geology of the mineral deposits of Australia and Papua New Guinea, v. 1: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 14, p. 671–675.; Pirajno, F., and Preston, W.A., 1998, Mineral deposits of the Padbury, Bryah and Yerrida basins, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 63–69.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.
Notes: Massive, dissemination, stringers, en echelon lenses, 50 m width.

References: Davies, B.M., and Blockley, J.G., 1990, Copper, lead, and zinc, in Geology and mineral resources of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia Memoir 3, p. 631–639.; Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.; Reynolds, D.G., Brook, W.A., Marshall, A.E., and Allchurch, P.D., 1975, Volcanogenic copper-zinc deposits in the Pilbara and Yilgarn Archean blocks, in Knight, C.L., ed., Economic geology of Australia and Papua New Guinea, 1. Metals: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph Series no. 5, pt. 1, p. 185–195.
Notes: 4 steeply dipping massive sulfide bodies, veinlets cut sulfide bodies, 4 m maximum thickness, plunge 20˚N, intense chlorite alteration, Fe-rich gossan outcrops, secondary enrichment Cu at 18-25 m depth. Resource 0.014 million t @ 18% Cu.

References: Donaldson, Mike, 2002, Kimberley Volcano: Kimberley Society talk 5 June 2002, http://www.kimberleysociety.org/past02.html (last accessed January 7, 2008).; Marston, R.J., 1979, Copper mineralization in Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia Mineral Resource Bulletin 13, 208 p.; Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.
Notes: Massive, stringer. Carson Volcanics, average 500 m thick, tholeiitic. Tectonic setting uncertain.

References: Morant, P., 1998, Panorama zinc-copper deposit, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 287–292.; Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.

Notes: Massive sulfide 30 m thickness. Surface gossan.

References: Barley, Mark, 1998, Archean volcanic-hosted massive sulphides: Australian Geological Survey Organisation Journal of Australian Geology and Geophysics, v. 17, no. 4, p. 69–73.; Morant, P., 1998, Panorama zinc-copper deposit, in Berkman, D.A., and Mackenzie, D.H., eds., Geology of Australian and Papua New Guinean mineral deposits: The Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph 22, p. 287–292.; Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.
Notes: Massive Zn cap below marker chert, massive Cu-rich middle, basal stringer, separated by 10 m of uneconomic zone. Surface gossan. Stringer of quartz, pyrite, chalcopyrite, minor sphalerite and carbonate veins. Pb-Pb galena age 3257+/-8 Ma.

References: Davies, B.M., and Blockley, J.G., 1990, Copper, lead, and zinc, in Geology and mineral resources of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia Memoir 3, p. 631–639.; Marston, R.J., 1979, Copper mineralization in Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia Mineral Resource Bulletin 13, 208 p.; Myers, J.S., and Hocking, R.M., 1988, Geologic map of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia, 1:2,500,000.; Preston, W.A., Keats, W., and Hickman, A.H., 1988, Mineral deposits of Western Australia: Geological Survey of Western Australia 1988 Centennial Edition, 2nd edition, 1:2,500,000.; Nickel, E.H., 1982, The mineralogy and geochemistry of the Whim Creek gossan: Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Proceedings no. 282, p. 33–45.; Reynolds, D.G., Brook, W.A., Marshall, A.E., and Allchurch, P.D., 1975, Volcanogenic copper-zinc deposits in the Pilbara and Yilgarn Archean blocks, in Knight, C.L., ed., Economic geology of Australia and Papua New Guinea, 1. Metals: The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Monograph Series no. 5, pt. 1, p. 185–195.
Notes: Several lenses, massive, barren granular pyrite capping. 2 deposits: Whundo and West Whundo, shoots pinch out at depth and along strike. Surface gossan. Intense chlorite alteration below and along strike to deposits.

References: Biste, Michael, and Gourlay, A.W., 2000, Geology and setting of the Miguela A-Zone, Guarayos Greenstone Belt, eastern Bolivia, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 359–374.; Pareja L., Jorge, compiler, 1978, Mapa geologico de Bolivia: Yacimientos Petrolíferos Fiscales Bolivianos and Servicio Geológico de Bolivia, scale 1:1,000,000.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Minimum tonnage 1.62 million t @ 3.76% Cu, 0.33% Zn, 1.26 g/t Au, 11.3 g/t Ag. Massive to disseminated. 3 bodies in two stratigraphic layers: Western A-1 and A-2 in upper horizon, Eastern A-3 in lower horizon, separated by 300 m; A-1 is massive tabular 12-23 m thick, 450 m strike length, 350 m down-dip extent, open, A-2 is massive and semi-massive, A-3 is disseminated pyrite; 40 m thick oxide zone, 45 m supergene zone. Tholeiitic-calc alkaline.

References: Schobbenhaus, Carlos, Derze, G.R., Almeida Campos, D., and others, 1981, Mapa geológico do Brasil e da área oceânica adjacente includindo depósitos minerais: Departmento Nacional da Produção Mineral, scale 1:2,500,000.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.; Staff of Anglo American Brasil, and Kerr, David, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide mineralization in the Aripauanã District of Mato Grosso, Brazil, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 447–451.;
Notes: Massive to disseminated, tabular and lenticular bodies, recrystallized, remobilized. Age 1770-1750. Has been classified as epithermal veins. Epicontinental rift setting. Preliminary resource 12 million t @ 6.3% Zn, 2.2% Pb, open.

Most recent reserves is 8 million t with no grades reported. Earlier reserves stated at 6.35 million t @ 0.6% Cu, 2.5% Zn, 0.5 g/t Au, 20 g/t Ag. Not fully explored.

Notes: Stratiform and discordant, massive to semi-massive bodies. Gossan at surface. 21B Zone is 900 m long, 200 m wide, 1-15 m thick.  Combined with HW Zone, 109 Zone, 21C Zone, 21A Zone, Pumphouse Zone, East Block, Pathfinder Zone, NEX Zone. Bimodal.  In part epithermal Au-Ag. Sb and Hg also produced as by-products. Island arc (tholeiitic). Production plus reserves to 2004 was 2.63 million t @ 0.13% Cu, 0.94% Zn, 0.48% Pb, 58 g/t Au, 2618 g/t Ag, open. Geological reserves for the 21 Zone was 4.3 million t @ 28.8 g/t Au, 1027 g/t Ag.

Notes: Massive and stockwork dissemination, in 8 bodies. Tholeiitic basalt. Note: Cu grade calculated from production plus resources, Au and Ag grades projected from past production. Minfile classified this deposit as a Cyprus-type, but lack of ophiolite sequence and abundant pelitic sediments would tend to put it in the pelitic-mafic type class. Early discovery suggests deposit was exposed at the surface.

Original resource 0.254 million t @ 0.28% Cu, 2.23% Zn, 1.27% Pb, 0.6 g/t Au, 257 g/t Ag. Recent proven reserves 1.011 million t @ 0.55% Cu, 4.0% Zn, 2.5% Pb, 240 g/t Ag; not fully explored.

Notes: Dissemination, massive. 3 en echelon lenses: Kutcho, Sumac West, and Esso West. Conformable to bedding, Kutcho has 1400 m length, 27 m thickness and crops out on surface. U-Pb age 244-246. Upper footwall is cut by pyrite-quartz veins which are now thought to be tectonically flattened stockwork veins. Fore-arc oceanic basin adjacent to primitive tholeiitic island arc (alkaline arc magmas).

No. 3 is similar to No. 2 but slightly discordant to host rocks along strike. No. 4 is the largest lens extends from 457 to 1402 m depth, strike length is 90 m, width 39 m, dips 20-60˚, avg. 42˚, with a disseminated or stringer zone at the west end. A, D, and G are smaller lenses in the hangingwall of No. 1. Island arc tholeiite.

The Ansil mine: Canadian Journal of Earth Science, v. 28, p. 1699–1730.; Caumartin, C., 1991, The Mobrun polymetallic massive sulphide deposit, in Tourigny, G., and Verpaelst, P., eds., Control on the base metal and gold mineralizations, Bousquet–Rouyn–Noranda area: Toronto, Society of Economic Geologists Guidebook Series v. 10, Field Conference, 20–24 May 1991, p. 118–129.; Franklin, J.M., Gibson, H.L., Jonasson, I.R., and Galley, A.G., 2005, Volcanogenic massive sulfide deposits, in Hedenquist, J.W., Thompson, J.H.F., Goldfarb, R.J., and Richards, J.P., eds., Economic Geology 100th anniversary volume: Littleton, Colorado, Society of Economic Geologists, p. 523–560, CD Supplemental Appendices, 45 p. including table 1.; Salmon, Bernard, 1991, Underground tour—Ansil mine, in Tourigny, G., and Verpaelst, P., eds., Control on the base metal and gold mineralizations, Bousquet–Rouyn–Noranda area: Toronto, Society of Economic Geologists Guidebook Series v. 10, Field Conference, 20–24 May 1991, p. 129–142.;
Notes: Massive sulfide, ellipsoidal, E-dipping, two main lenses interconnected with thinner interval of massive sulfides, west end is well banded to massive, east end is massive and capped by magnetite 10-35 m thick. Stringer zone beneath orebody consists of network of chlorite and disseminated and stringer sulfides and magnetite; magnetite has its own separate feeder zone. In contact between andesite and rhyolite. These volcanic rocks are transitional between tholeiitic and calc-alkaline, but closer to tholeiitic. Deepest deposit in the Noranda district and rich Cu grade.

Notes: Massive to semi-massive lenses, at least 5 lenses, extends from the surface to a vertical depth of 760 m, 1.3 km strike length, trends 290˚, dips 50˚N, plunge variable due to folding. Brown Lens is sub-economic. Amber Lens is well defined. Blue Lens open at depth, Blue FW East open along strike, Lower Red Lens open in all directions. Resource 4.54 million t @ 3.73% Zn, 0.25% Cu, 12 g/t Ag (1% Zn cutoff) or 1.68 million t @ 6.79% Zn, 0.27% Cu, 18.5 g/t Ag (3% Zn cutoff).

Notes: Massive, disseminations, 0.00899 km thickness. Lens in shear zone. Beneath Hanson Lake. Not same as McIlvenna Bay (Hanson Lake) deposit. Age based on quartz porphyry stocks. Primitive arc tholeiites to evolved calc-alkaline island arc.

Plunge 35-50˚E, slightly steeper than regional fold axis 10-20˚E. Two ore types, sulfide lens in tremolite skarn and disseminations in cordierite-anthophyllite.

Notes: Massive, dissemination, stockwork, long and narrow, digitated, doubly convex, polygonal, pencil-like, wedge-shaped; large pods 2-30 m wide, 40-80 m long, 2-15 m high; ore zone 800 m long, quartz-pyrite-chalcopyrite stringer zone. Fault bounds deposit on E side. Dikes of basalt divide the deposit into smaller blocks. Ocean crust ophiolite.

References: QGX Ltd., 2008, Golden Hills: web site, http://www.qgxgold.com/html/shtml/qgx_projects_golden.shtml (last accessed February 8, 2008).; Sandefur, R.L., and Chlumsky, G.F., 2007, Preliminary economic assessment Central Valley Zone Golden Hills Project, Mongolia: Chlumsky, Armbrust and Meyer, LLC, report prepared for QGX Ltd., 136 p.;
Notes: Massive, semi-massive, veins, three zones, North, Central, South zones. South Zone is 300 m south of North Zone. Up to 60 m wide. North Zone traced for over 1 km strike length, 10-63 m thick, from 70 m to 350 m below surface, 400 m down-dip, dips 55˚N. Remobilized Au-Te-quartz veins occur around the margins of the North Zone. Associated supergene and buried gossan oxide zones. Feeder zone beneath massive sulfide body. Resources 19.7 million t @ 1.51% Cu, 0.36 g/t Au, 4.9 g/t Ag, open at depth and laterally.

References: Dagbert, Michel, and Harfi, Mohamed, 2002, Resource estimation for the Draa Sfar South polymetallic deposit: Exploration and Mining Geology, v. 11, nos. 1–4, p. 99–112.; Mining Technology, 2008, Hajar metal mine, Morocco: http://www.mining-technology.com/projects/hajar/ (last accessed February 7, 2008).
Notes: Massive, curving layer. North and South orebodies, nearly vertical, down to 900 m depth (South deposit). Minimum reserves 8 million t 0.27% Cu, 5.52% Zn, 2.3% Pb, plus Au and Ag, open at depth. Startup and shutdown in 1981 due to mining and milling problems, producing only a few tens of thousands tonnes of ore.

Notes: domal shape, 70 m thick, several smaller lenses at same stratigraphic level, associated barite and magnetite lenses laterally. Lens 600 m long, 6-70 m thick. Remobilized in upper part by limestone replacement. 3 types of ore: massive barite with sulfides, stringers of barite and sulfides, massive magnetite with sulfides. Zoned upper disseminated barite-jasper-Pb-Zn sulfides, intermediate barite-Ag-sulfosalts-Pb-Zn sulfides, lower barite-Pb-Zn-Cu sulfides-sulfosalts. Stockwork feeder zone beneath Vulcano orebody. Ore depleted.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Guadalajara: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Hall, B.V., and Gomez-Torres, P.P., 2000, Geology of the kuroko-type massive sulphide deposits of the Cuale district, Jalisco State, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 141–161.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Massive sulfides, dissemination, shoots, balls, small pipes, irregular streaks, lenses. La Prieta 900 m strike length, 200 m vertical depth, shoots 30-70 m long, 70-80 m high, 10 m thick; Prietita 150 m strike length, 3-15 m thick, dip 10-45˚N at 50 m depth; Coloradita 120 m long, 80 m wide, 11 m thick; Corozon 150 m long, 60 m wide stockwork; pyrite-quartz stockwork in footwall of Chivos de Arriba. Calc-alkaline island arc setting.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Mexico: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Oliver, Jim, Payne, John, Rebagliati, Mark, and Cluff, Robert, 2000, Precious-metal-bearing volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits, Camp Morado, Guererro, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 57–69.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Massive sulfide lenses at 3 stratigraphic levels, stringers. Upper lens oxidized and strongly leached. Lower two lenses and related stringer zones. Zoned with upper Au-Ag-Pb-Zn, central Cu, lower Cu-Zn-Au; stockwork of quartz-pyrite-chalcopyrite-chlorite. Fault offsets deposit. Calc-alkaline island arc setting. Inferred reserves 9.7 million t @ 0.76% Cu, 1.91% Zn, 0.51% Pb, 1.4 g/t Au, 69 g/t Ag, open.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Mexico: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Miranda-Gasca, M.A., 1995, The volcanogenic massive sulfide and sedimentary exhalative deposits of the Guerrero Terrane, Mexico: University of Arizona, Ph. D. dissertation, 294 p.; Oliver, Jim, Payne, John, Rebagliati, Mark, and Cluff, Robert, 2000, Precious-metal-bearing volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits, Camp Morado, Guererro, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 57–69.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Massive sulfide, zoned with lower Cu-rich, central pyrite-rich, upper Pb-Zn-rich zones. El Rey 200 m long, 40 m high; Reforma 400 m long, 50 m high. Both are 200 m apart. Overturned limb of major N-NE recumbent anticline; Reforma truncated by fault on SE, N-dipping extensional fault on SW side; El Rey is cut by extensional normal to oblique faults; bedding overturned. Calc-alkaline island arc setting. Inferred reserves 9.7 million t @ 0.66% Cu, 2.14% Zn, 0.7% Pb, 1.77 g/t Au, 107 g/t Ag, partially defined.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Guadalajara: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Hall, B.V., and Gomez-Torres, P.P., 2000, Geology of the kuroko-type massive sulphide deposits of the Cuale district, Jalisco State, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 141–161.; Miranda-Gasca, M.A., 1995, The volcanogenic massive sulfide and sedimentary exhalative deposits of the Guerrero Terrane, Mexico: University of Arizona, Ph. D. dissertation, 294 p.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: 2 horizons at Naricero 30 m apart, massive and disseminations, 390 m long, 195 m wide, 2.7 m thick. Normal faults offset bed 30 m. Calc-alkaline island arc setting.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Mexico: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Giles, D.A., and Garcia, F.J., 2000, Volcanogenic deposits in Mexico—The producing mines, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 135–140.; Miranda-Gasca, M.A., 1995, The volcanogenic massive sulfide and sedimentary exhalative deposits of the Guerrero Terrane, Mexico: University of Arizona, Ph. D. dissertation, 294 p.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Several sulfide lenses and bodies. Zoned with Cu upwards, Zn-Pb downwards, capped by jasper. Tehuixtla is largest body, 250 m below surface, 2-18 m thick, dips 25˚SW, lenticular, with stockwork feeder zone beneath it. Barite lenses common. Quartz-sericite-pyrite halo up to 150 m over the ore layer. Calc-alkaline island arc setting.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Guadalajara: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Hall, B.V., and Gomez-Torres, P.P., 2000, Geology of the kuroko-type massive sulphide deposits of the Cuale district, Jalisco State, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 141–161.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Stockwork, veins, veinlets, pipes, 5-6 m diameter, Grandeza (Minas del Oro) 125 m long, 70 m high, 20-50 m wide elliptical seams, pockets, pipes; Las Talpas 150 m SE of Grandeza, 2 steep pipe-like bodies of veins and disseminations, 100 m vertical extent, 10-25 m wide; San Juan 2 m thick cross-cutting veins. Calc-alkaline island arc setting.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Guadalajara: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Imdex, Inc., 2007, Mining companies in Mexico (T): website, http://www.imdex.com/c_t.htm (last accessed September 21, 2007).; Johnson, B.J., Montante-Martinez, J.A., Canela-Barboza, Mario, 2000, Geology of the San Nicolas deposit, Zacatecas, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 71–85.; Phillips, Nigel, and Oldenburg, D.W., 2002, Geophysical inversion in an integrated mineral exploration program: examples from the San Nicolas deposit: web site, http://www.geop.ubc.ca/ubcgif/pubs/seg2002/np-seg2002.pdf (last accessed July 24, 2002).; Sillitoe, R.H., 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide copper-zinc deposit, in Exploration and Discovery of Base- and Precious-Metal Deposits in the Circum-Pacific Region–A Late 1990s Update: Resource Geology Special Issue no. 21, p. 38–40.; Thompson, J.F.H., 1999, Discovery of new deposits at depth—Examples of a flexible approach to exploration: Sydney Mineral Exploration Discussion Group Symposium, Exploration Under Cover, 24 Sept. 1999, Keynote Address, 6 p., website, http://www.smedg.org.au/Sym99Keynote.htm (last accessed September 21, 2007).
Notes: Massive, semi-massive, stringers, Lower Sulfide Zone is tabular, Main Sulfide Zone is elongate 900 m long, 400 m wide, 28 m thick. Zoned with increasing Zn upwards, increasing Cu and pyrite downwards. This is the largest VMS deposit in Mexico. Age 152-124. Preliminary estimates of resources 99.5 million t @ 1.36% Cu, 1.64% Zn, 0.15% Pb, 0.41 g/t Au, 24 g/t Ag, open.

References: Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Guadalajara: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Giles, D.A., and Garcia, F.J., 2000, Volcanogenic deposits in Mexico—The producing mines, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 135–140.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Massive sulfide lenses, stringers, disseminations, 1200 m long, 2-80 m thick, strike NW, dips 40-75˚SW. Network of quartz-sericite-pyrite in felsic rocks associated with upper portion of massive sulfide bodies. 2 fault systems, N70˚E and N10˚E, displace orebodies. Calc-alkaline island arc setting.

References: Cabral-Cano, Enrique, Lang, H.R., and Harrison, C.G.A., 2000, Stratigraphic assessment of the Arcelia-Teloloapan area, Southern Mexico—Implications for southern Mexico’s Post-Neocomian tectonic evolution: Journal of South American Earth Sciences, v. 13, no. 4–5, p. 443–357.; Direccion General de Geografia del Territorio Nacional, 1981, Carta geologica Mexico: scale 1:1,000,000 (in Spanish).; Giles, D.A., and Garcia, F.J., 2000, Volcanogenic deposits in Mexico—The producing mines, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 135–140.; Lewis P.D., and Rhys, D.A., 2000, Geologic setting of the Tizapa volcanogenic massive sulphide deposit, Mexico State, Mexico, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 87–112.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.
Notes: Massive pyrite-rich lenses, 5 main orebodies, 10-50 m apart, 3-14 m thick, in imbricated stacks due to faulting and folding. Widespread disseminations, bands, stringers pyrite-chalcopyrite in footwall (feeder zone). N-dipping fault cuts ore deposit. Calc-alkaline island arc setting.

References: Cox, R., Gaskell, J.L., and Thomas, C.M., 1981, Burma—A country with major unexplored mineral potential, in Asian Mining ‘81: London, The Institution of Mining and Metallurgy, p. 35–45.; Earth Science Research Division, 1977, The geological map of Burma: Burma, Research Policy Direction Board, scale 1:1,000,000.; Hutchinson, C.S., and Taylor, D., 1978, Metallogenesis in southeast Asia: Journal Geological Society of London, v. 135, p. 407–428.; Krishnan, M.S., 1982, Geology of India and Burma: Satish Kumar Jain, 536 p.; Laznicka, Peter, 1973, MANIFILE—the University of Manitoba file of nonferrous metal deposits of the world: Winnipeg, Manitoba, Department of Earth Sciences, University of Manitoba.; Loveman, M.H., 1917, The geology of the Bawdwin mines, Burma, Asia: Transactions of the American Institute of Mining Engineers, v. 56, p. 170–194.; United Nations, 1953, Development of mineral resources in Asia and the Far East: United Nations Mineral Resources Development Series no. 2, 366 p.; United Nations, 1960, Copper, lead and zinc ore resources of Asia and the Far East: Mineral Resources Development Series no. 14, 63 p.
Notes: Massive, vein or lens, interlacing seams, forming small stockworks, impregnation of the country rock. Chinaman Lode is the main ore body extends to depths of at least 198 m. Surface gossans. Mining by the Chinese ended about 1868, and redeveloped by the Europeans starting in 1901. Possible rifted continental shelf.

Stratigraphy may be inverted. Back arc marginal basin or off-axes ensialic intraplate incipient rift or ensimatic mid-oceanic ridge (mid-ocean ridge tholeiitic affinity).

Ophiolitic oceanic ridge axes (mid-ocean ridge tholeiitic affinity).

References: de las Casas, Fernando, and Ponzoni S., Edgardo, 1969, Peru mapa metallogenetico: Sociedad Nacional de Minería y Petróleo, scale 1:1,000,000.; Instituto de Geologia y Minería Peru, 1975, Mapa geologico del Peru: scale 1:1,000,000.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.; Steinmüller, Klaus, Abad, N.C., and Grant, Brian, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits in Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 423–437.; Zevallos, P.L., 2000, Cerro Lindo project, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 407–422.
Notes: Massive sulfides, baritic lens, irregular sulfide veins, Lens 4 stockwork of veins and disseminations, Lens 2 veinlets and disseminations to massive banding with overlying barite zone. Vertical zone: basal pyrite-chalcopyrite, upwards to sphalerite-galena to barite.  Belt 1 150 m wide, NW-SE strike, Belt 2 550 m strike NW-SE, 30-200 m wide, Belt 3 350 m N-S strike, 200 m wide. Gossan at surface. Rifted continental margin basin. Resource 75 million t @ 0.89% Cu, 3.28% Zn, 0.36% Pb, 50.7 g/t Ag, open laterally and vertically.

References: de las Casas, Fernando, and Ponzoni S., Edgardo, 1969, Peru mapa metallogenetico: Sociedad Nacional de Minería y Petróleo, scale 1:1,000,000.; Instituto de Geologia y Minería Peru, 1975, Mapa geologico del Peru: scale 1:1,000,000.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.; Steinmüller, Klaus, Abad, N.C., and Grant, Brian, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits in Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 423–437.
Notes: Deep massive sulfide zone, disseminations, veinlets, lenses with barite zones up to 12 m thick. Back arc rifted and continental margin basin.

References: de las Casas, Fernando, and Ponzoni S., Edgardo, 1969, Peru mapa metallogenetico: Sociedad Nacional de Minería y Petróleo, scale 1:1,000,000.; Instituto de Geologia y Minería Peru, 1975, Mapa geologico del Peru: scale 1:1,000,000.; Polliand, Marc, and Fontboté, Lluis, 2000, The Perubar Ba-Pb-Zn VHMS deposit, central Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 439–446.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.; Steinmüller, Klaus, Abad, N.C., and Grant, Brian, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits in Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 423–437.
Notes: Canete Basin, Casma Group, Eastern Facies. underlying stockwork zone, silicified, veinlets, disseminations, barite increases upwards. Rifted continental margin basin.

References: de las Casas, Fernando, and Ponzoni S., Edgardo, 1969, Peru mapa metallogenetico: Sociedad Nacional de Minería y Petróleo, scale 1:1,000,000.; Instituto de Geologia y Minería Peru, 1975, Mapa geologico del Peru: scale 1:1,000,000.; Steinmüller, Klaus, Abad, N.C., and Grant, Brian, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits in Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 423–437.
Notes: Stratabound disseminated, stringers, breccias at Raul, stratiform bodies at Condestable. Vein subordinate at Raul in NE- and E-trending systems. In part Cu skarn. Age 128 (K-Ar). Back arc, stratovolcano on marine platform, in part subaerial.

References: de las Casas, Fernando, and Ponzoni S., Edgardo, 1969, Peru mapa metallogenetico: Sociedad Nacional de Minería y Petróleo, scale 1:1,000,000.; Instituto de Geologia y Minería Peru, 1975, Mapa geologico del Peru: scale 1:1,000,000.; Sherlock Ross, and Michaud, Michael, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America—An overview, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 19–46.; Steinmüller, Klaus, Abad, N.C., and Grant, Brian, 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits in Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 423–437.; Tegart, Peter, Allen, Gordon, and Carstensen, Andrew, 2000, Regional setting, stratigraphy, alteration and mineralization of the Tambo Grande VMS district, Piura Department, northern Peru, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 375–405.
Notes: TG-1, Oxide Cap, massive sulfides 950 m long, 350 m wide, 200 m thick. TG-3 500 m wide, 300 m thick, multiple stacks of lenses flanking a dacite dome, 500 m south of TG-1. TG-1 has a stringer zone of quartz-pyrite-chlorite-chalcopyrite-calcite-barite. Tholeiitic-subalkaline volcanics. Back arc rifted continental margin basin.

Notes: Massive, stockwork, 0.15 km thickness. Stockwork ore exposed at the surface, massive ore 50 m below surface. Orebody extends 2700 m E-W strike, 30-200 m horizontal thickness, surface to 550 m depth. Overturned beds. Multiple ductile-brittle shears (south-verging imbrications, sinistral transverse strike slip-faults) resulted in offsets and repeats of the ore horizon.

Notes: Two main ore bodies of massive and banded pyrite, 1 km long, between 400 and 850 m depth. Upper ore body up to 70 m thick, lenses and blankets of massive sulfides and stockwork zones, over 100 m thick. Lower orebody is smaller and thinner (incompletely explored). Three main ore type: Complex ore 11.0 million t @ 0.54% Cu, 5.0% Pb+Zn, 0.76 g/t Au; Cupriferous ore 1.3 million t @ 1.91% Cu, 1.7% Pb+Zn, 0.10 g/t Au; Pyrite ore 80 million t @ 0.40% Cu, 1.5% Pb+Zn, 0.10 g/t Au. Total tonnage 120 million t @ 0.5% Cu, 1.3% Zn, 0.6% Pb, 0.8 g/t Au, 38 g/t Ag, open.

Notes: Massive, dissemination, 2-10 m thick, extremely elongate shape, slightly oblique to the generally NNW axial direction of the F2 folds. Disseminated ore beneath the massive ore is irregular and pyrrhotite-rich, may be the feeder zone. Stratigraphy may be inverted. Contains 18.76% S. Remobilization. Rifted ensimatic island arc (immobile trace elements indicate a mixture of mildly tholeiitic island arc volcanites and strongly tholeiitic to alkaline rifting-type basalts), thought to have formed in an incipient intra-arc rift.

Notes: Massive, single lens, very coarse grained sulfides. 600 m strike length, 100 m wide, 45 m thick. Tholeiitic back arc or intra arc oceanic basin, possibly floored by oceanic crust. Ore expected to be depleted in 2007.

Stringer zone in upper ore body is 100 m thick. Lower ore body is 140 m long, 15 m thick, and is exposed. Fine-grained gypsum occurs as small pockets (few cm diameter) in the hangingwall pyroclastics. Island arc extensional basin.

References: Emmons, W.H., 1910, Some ore deposits in Maine and the Milan mine, New Hampshire: U.S. Geological Survey Bulletin 432, 61 p.; Gair, J.E., and Slack, J.F., 1979, Map showing lithostratigraphic and structural setting of stratabound (massive) sulfide deposits in U.S. Appalachians: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 79-1517, scale 1:1,000,000, 4 sheets.; Lyons, J.B., Bothner, W.A., Moench, R.H., and Thompson, J.B., Jr., 1997, Bedrock geologic map of New Hampshire: U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of Energy, and State of New Hampshire, scale 1:250,000.
Notes: Massive, dissemination, overlapping lenses, 0.008 km thickness. No wallrock alteration. North and South orebodies overlap and bends in strike and dip directions. South orebody crops out.

References: Gair, J.E., and Slack, J.F., 1979, Map showing lithostratigraphic and structural setting of stratabound (massive) sulfide deposits in U.S. Appalachians: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 79-1517, scale 1:1,000,000, 4 sheets.; Lyons, J.B., Bothner, W.A., Moench, R.H., and Thompson, J.B., Jr., 1997, Bedrock geologic map of New Hampshire: U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of Energy, and State of New Hampshire, scale 1:250,000.
Notes: Massive thick lens 0.003 km thickness.

References: Dane, C.H., and Bachman, G.O., 1965, Geologic map of New Mexico: U.S. Geological Survey, The New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, State Bureau of Mines nad Mineral Resources Division, and University of New Mexico Department of Geology, 1:500,000.; Dane, C.H., and Bachman, G.O., 1965, Topography and geology, in Mineral and Water Resources of New Mexico: U.S. Geological Survey, New Mexico Bureau of Mines and Mineral Resources, New Mexico State Engineer Office, New Mexico Oil Conservation Commission: Washington, U.S. Government Printing Office, p. 19–39.; Hunt, C.B., 1977, Surficial geology of northeast New Mexico: New Mexico Bureau of Mines and Mineral Resources Geologic Map 40, scale 1:500,000.; Kreiger, Philip, 1932, Geology of the zinc-lead deposit at Pecos, New Mexico: Economic Geology, v. 27, no. 4, p. 344–365.; Robertson, J.M., Condie, K.C., and Mathewson, D.C., 1978, The Pecos greenstone belt—A Proterozoic volcano-sedimentary sequence in the southern Sangre De Cristo Mountains, New Mexico [abs.]: Geological Association of Canada and Mineralogical Association of Canada, Annual Meeting, Quebec, Oct. 23-26, Abstracts with Programs, v. 3, p. 479.
Notes: Dissemination, massive. Evangeline and Katydid orebodies.

References: Johnson, M.G., 1977, Geology and mineral deposits of Pershing County, Nevada: Nevada Bureau of Mines and Geology Bulletin 89, 115 p.; Rye, R.O., Roberts, Ralph, Snyder, W.S., Lahusen, L.S., and Motica, John, 1984, Textural and sulfur isotopic studies of the Big Mike volcanogenic massive sulfide deposit, Pershing County, Nevada: Economic Geology, v. 79, no. 1, p. 124–140.
Notes: Massive len (pyrite-chalcopyrite-sphalerite), 0.015 km thickness. Stringer of veinlets (quartz-pyrite-carbonate-sericite-chalcopyrite-sphalerite) in footwall and hangingwall. Rift ocean basin ophiolite.

References: Juhas, A.P., Freeman, P.S., and Fredericksen, R.S., 1980, Kuroko-type copper-gold mineralization at the Iron Dyke mine, Oregon, in Silberman, M.L., Field, C.W., and Berry, A.L., eds., Symposium on mineral deposits of the Pacific Northwest, Geological Society of America, Cordilleran Section Meeting, Corvallis, Oregon, March 20-21, 1980, Proceedings: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 81-355, p. 236–245.; Walker, G.W., and MacLeod, N.S., 1991, Geologic map of Oregon: U.S. Geological Survey, scale 1:500,000.
Notes: Stringer. anastomosing network of quartz-chalcopyrite-pyrite veinlets in pipe-like feeder zone.

References: Hundhausen, R.J., 1956, Preliminary investigation of the Takilma-Waldo copper district, Josephine Co., Oregon: U.S. Bureau of Mines RI 5187, 22 p.; Koski, R.A., and Derkey, R.E., 1981, Massive sulfide deposits in ocean-crust and island-arc terranes of southwestern Oregon: Oregon Geology, v. 43, no. 9, p. 119–125.; Ramp, Len, and Peterson, N.V., 1979, Geology and mineral resources of Josephine County, Oregon: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries Bulletin 100, 45 p.; Shenon, P.J., 1933, Geology and ore deposits of the Takilma-Waldo district, Oregon, including the Blue Creek district: U.S. Geological Survey Bulletin 846-B, p. 141–194.; Walker, G.W., and MacLeod, N.S., 1991, Geologic map of Oregon: U.S. Geological Survey, scale 1:500,000.; Wells, F.G., Bell, G.L., Cater, F.W., Jr., Hotz, P.E., and James, H.L., 1948, Preliminary geologic map of the Kerby Quadrangle, Oregon: Oregon State Department of Geology and Mineral Industries, scale 1:96,000.
Notes: Massive, 0.02 km thickness, pods, wedges, tabular lenses. Ocean crust ophiolite.

References: Koski, R.A., and Derkey, R.E., 1981, Massive sulfide deposits in ocean-crust and island-arc terranes of southwestern Oregon: Oregon Geology, v. 43, no. 9, p. 119–125.; Ramp, Len, and Peterson, N.V., 1979, Geology and mineral resources of Josephine County, Oregon: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries Bulletin 100, 45 p.; Shenon, P.J., 1933, Geology and ore deposits of the Takilma-Waldo district, Oregon, including the Blue Creek district: U.S. Geological Survey Bulletin 846-B, p. 141–194.; Strickler, M.D., 1986, Geologic setting of the Turner-Albright massive sulfide deposit: Oregon Geology, v. 48, no. 10, October 1986, p. 115-122. ; Walker, G.W., and MacLeod, N.S., 1991, Geologic map of Oregon: U.S. Geological Survey, scale 1:500,000.
Notes: Massive, stringer, dissemination. 2 gossan zones. NNE strike, 30˚SE to nearly vertical dip. Ophiolite, back-arc rift basin. Contains average 0.05% Co.

References: Pavlides, Louis, Gair, J.E., and Cranford, S.L., 1982, Central Virginia volcanic-plutonic belt as a host for massive sulfide deposits, in Massive sulfide deposits of the southern Appalachians: Economic Geology, v. 77, no. 2, p. 233–272.; Stephens, M.B., Swinden, H.S., and Slack, J.F., 1984, Correlation of massive sulfide deposits in the Appalachian-Caledonian orogen on the basis of paleotectonic setting: Economic Geology, v. 79, no. 7, p. 1442–1478.; Young, R.S., 1981, Sulfide zones, in Geologic investigations in the Willis Mountain and Andersonville quadrangles, Virginia: Virginia Division of  Mineral Resources Publication 29, p. 17–47.
Notes: Zn-rich massive sulfides, Zone 18, 60% pyrite. Surface gossans. Calc-alkaline.

References: Pavlides, Louis, Gair, J.E., and Cranford, S.L., 1982, Central Virginia volcanic-plutonic belt as a host for massive sulfide deposits, in Massive sulfide deposits of the southern Appalachians: Economic Geology, v. 77, no. 2, p. 233–272.; Stephens, M.B., Swinden, H.S., and Slack, J.F., 1984, Correlation of massive sulfide deposits in the Appalachian-Caledonian orogen on the basis of paleotectonic setting: Economic Geology, v. 79, no. 7, p. 1442–1478.; Young, R.S., 1981, Sulfide zones, in Geologic investigations in the Willis Mountain and Andersonville quadrangles, Virginia: Virginia Division of  Mineral Resources Publication 29, p. 17–47.
Notes: 3 zones of Zn-rich massive sulfides, Zone 24, Zone 5, Zone 6. 3 stratigraphic lenses within Zone 24: upper (Cu-Zn-rich), middle (pyrite-Zn-rich), lower (pyrite-Zn-rich). Surface gossans. Calc-alkaline.

References: Gair, J.E., and Slack, J.F., 1984, Deformation, geochemistry, and origin of massive sulfide deposits, Gossan Lead District, Virginia: Economic Geology, v. 79, no. 7,  p. 1483–1520.; Henry, D.K., Craig, J.R., and Gilbert, M.C., 1979, ORE MINERALOGY OF THE GREAT Gossan Lead, Virginia: Economic Geology, v.74, no. 3, p. 645–656.
Notes: Discontinuous lenses of massive sulfides. Gossan Howard 90 m long, >60 m wide, 12-20 m thick; Huey 115 m long, 60 m wide, 3-9 m thick; Bumbarger 150 m long, 70 m wide, 30 m thick. Oceanic rift.

References: Gair, J.E., and Slack, J.F., 1979, Map showing lithostratigraphic and structural setting of stratabound (massive) sulfide deposits of the U.S. Appalachians: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 79-1517, scale 1:1,000,000.; Pavlides, Louis, Gair, J.E., and Cranford, S.L., 1982, Massive sulfide deposits of the southern Appalachians: Economic Geology, v. 77, no. 2, p. 233–272.
Notes: Two parallel tabular lenses. Tholeiitic and calc-alkaline island arc.

References: Gair, J.E., and Slack, J.F., 1979, Map showing lithostratigraphic and structural setting of stratabound (massive) sulfide deposits in U.S. Appalachians: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 79-1517, scale 1:1,000,000, 4 sheets.; Shanks, W.C., III, Woodruff, L.G., and Slack, J.F., 1985, Sulfur and oxygen isotope study of the Vermont copper belt—Evidence of seawater hydrothermal alteration and sulfate reduction in a high-grade metamorphic terrane [abs.]: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs, v. 17, no. 98, p. 713.; Slack, John F., 1998, Discussion on The timing and direction of metamorphic fluid flow in Vermont, by A.D.L. Skelton, 1996 (in Contributions to Mineralogy and Petrology, v. 125, p. 75–84): Contributions to Mineralogy and Petrology, v. 132, p. 106–109.
Notes: Massive lens, dissemination. Tholeiitic amphibolite.

References: Derkey, R.E., Joseph, N.L., and Lasmanis, Raymond, 1990, Metal mines of Washington—Preliminary report: Washington Division of Geology and Earth Resources Open-File Report 90–18, 577 p.; Dragovich, J.D., and Derkey, R.E., 1994, A Late Triassic island-arc setting for the Holden volcanogenic massive sulfide deposit, north Cascades, Washington: Washington Geology, v. 22, no. 1, p. 28–39.; Huntting, M.T., 1956, Inventory of Washington minerals, Part II, Metallic minerals: Washington Division of Mines and Geology Bulletin no. 37, 428 p.; Kilburn, J.E., Whitney, G.C., d’Angelo, W.M., Fey, D.L., Hopkins, R.T., Meier, A.L., Motooka, J.M., Roushey, B.H., and Sutley, S.J., 1994, Geochemical data and sample locality maps for stream-sediment, heavy-mineral-concentrate, mill tailing, water, and precipitate samples collected in and around the Holden mine, Chelan County, Washington: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 94-680A, 33 p.; Nold, J.L., 1983, The Holden Mine, a metamorphosed volcanogenic deposit in the Cascade Range of Washington: Economic Geology, v. 78, no. 5, p. 944–953.; Youngberg, E.A., and Wilson, T.L., 1952, The geology of the Holden mine: Economic Geology, v. 47, no. 1, p. 1–12.
Notes: Production 9.1 million t @ 1.06% Cu, 0.2% Zn, 6.9 g/t Ag, 2.1 g/t Au. Mine closed in 1957 because of high operating cost; an unknown amount of reserves remain. Mostly disseminated ore, local massive ore. Stratigraphy is overturned, but corrected in our rocks fields. Assays: 0.2-0.16% Ni, 0.19% U3O8 equivalent in one sample.

References: Engineering and Mining Journal, 1977, v. 176, no. 6, p. 264.; Gries, J.P., 1979, Providing new sources of mineral supply: U.S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 8789, p. 11.; Mudrey, M.G., Jr., 1979, The massive sulfide occurrences in Wisconsin: Wisconsin Geological and Natural History Survey Miscellaneous Paper 79-2, 20 p.; Mudrey, M.G., Brown, B.A., and Greenberg, J.K., 1982, Bedrock geologic map of Wisconsin: University of Wisconsin–Extension, Geological and Natural History Survey, scale 1:1,000,000.; Schmidt, P.G., Dolence, J.D., Lluria, M.R., and Parsons, G., III, 1978, Geology of Crandon massive sulfide deposit in Wisconsin: Skillings’ Mining Review, v. 67, no. 18, p. 8–11.; Wisconsin Exploration and Predevelopment Staff, Exxon Minerals Company, 1978, The discovery, geology and mineralogy of the Crandon Precambrian massive sulfide deposit, Wisconsin [abs.]: Quebec, Geological Association of Canada, Mineralogical Association of Canada, Annual Meeting, Oct. 23-26, Abstracts with Programs, v. 3, p. 518.
Notes: Zinc-rich massive tabular body, copper-rich stringer, elliptical lens. Ore body beneath 30-60 m glacial drift.

References: Afifi, Afifa, Doe, B.R., Sims, P.K., and Delevaux, M.H., 1984, U-Th-Pb isotope chronology of sulfide ores and rocks in the Early Proterozoic metavolcanic belt of northern Wisconsin: Economic Geology, v. 79, no. 2,  p. 338–353.; May, E.R., 1977, Flambeau–a Precambrian supergene enriched massive sulfide deposit: Madison, University of Wisconsin, Geoscience Wisconsin, v. 1, p. 1–26.; Mudrey, M.G., Jr., 1979, The massive sulfide occurrences in Wisconsin: Wisconsin Geological and Natural History Survey Miscellaneous Paper 79-2, 20 p.; Mudrey, M.G., Brown, B.A., and Greenberg, J.K., 1982, Bedrock geologic map of Wisconsin: University of Wisconsin–Extension, Geological and Natural History Survey, scale 1:1,000,000.; Mudrey, M.G., Evans, T.J., Babcock, R.C., Jr., Cummings, M.L., Jr., Eisenbrey, E.H., and LaBerge, G.L., 1983, Case history of metallic mineral exploration in Wisconsin, 1955 to 1982: unpublished paper, 75 p.
Notes: Massive, dissemination, 0.02 km thickness, vertically-oriented lens-shaped pod. Overturned beds.

References: Gries, J.P., 1979, Providing new sources of mineral supply: U.S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 8789, p. 11.; Mudrey, M.G., Jr., 1979, The massive sulfide occurrences in Wisconsin: Wisconsin Geological and Natural History Survey Miscellaneous Paper 79-2, 20 p.; Mudrey, M.G., Brown, B.A., and Greenberg, J.K., 1982, Bedrock geologic map of Wisconsin: University of Wisconsin–Extension, Geological and Natural History Survey, scale 1:1,000,000.; Mudrey, M.G., Evans, T.J., Babcock, R.C., Jr., Cummings, M.L., Jr., Eisenbrey, E.H., and LaBerge, G.L., 1983, Case history of metallic mineral exploration in Wisconsin, 1955 to 1982: unpublished paper, 75 p.; Wiggins, L.B., and Brett, R., 1977, Pelican River Cu-Zn deposit, Wisconsin—Metamorphic conditions in Penokean time [abs.]: Geological Society of America Abstract Program, v. 9, no. 7, p. 1226–1227.

Notes: Concordant tabular massive sulfide bodies in pyroclastic rocks and in dolomite horizon, accompanied by dissemination. Carboniferous back-arc basin along northern margin of the Baisun Precambrian massif.

References: Pankrat’ev, P.V., 1983, The Khandiza massive sulfide deposit, in Ivanov, S.N., ed., Massive sulfide deposits of the USSR: Moscow, Nauka Publishing House, p. 190–197 (in Russian).; Pankrat’ev, P.V., and Mikhailova, Y.V., 1971, Polymetallic massive sulfide mineralization in south Uzbekistan: Tashkent, FAN Publishing House, 186 p. Concordant brecciated massive sulfide lenses in limestone at the contact with rhyolite porphyry subvolcanic. Carboniferous back-arc basin along northern margin of the Baisun Precambrian massif.

References: Herrington, R.J., Achmedov, N.A., and Charter, W.J., 2005, The Khandiza Zn-Pb-Cu-Ag VMS deposit—Part a new ‘Bathurst District’ in southern Uzbekistan?, in Mao, J., and Bierlein, F.P., eds., Mineral deposits research—Meeting the global challenge: Eighth Biennial SGA Meeting, Beijin, China, 18–21 August, 2005, Proceedings: Springer, v. 1, p. 615–618.; Pankrat’ev, P.V., 1983, The Khandiza massive sulfide deposit, in Ivanov, S.N., ed., Massive sulfide deposits of the USSR: Moscow, Nauka Publishing House, p. 190–197 (in Russian).; Pankrat’ev, P.V., and Mikhailova, Y.V., 1971, Polymetallic massive sulfide mineralization in south Uzbekistan: Tashkent, FAN Publishing House, 186 p. (in Russian).
Notes: Tonnage and grades are not available. In galena: ≤ 2758 g/t Ag, 0.2 to 0.4% Se, 0.4% Bi. Four concordant massive sulfide lenses and dissemination in andesite porphyry and dolomitic limestone. Carboniferous back-arc basin along northern margin of the Baisun Precambrian massif.

Notes: Numerous pods, veins and lenses

References: Bucher, W.H., compiler, 1950, Geologic–tectonic map of the United States of Venezuela: Geological Society of America, scale 1:1,000,000.; Carlson, G.G., 1977, Geology of the Bailadores, Venezuela, massive sulfide deposit: Economic Geology, v. 72, no. 6, p. 1131–1141.; Moya, E.R., 1977, Aspectos metalogenicos de los Andes Venezolanos: Congresso Geologico Venezolano, V, Caracas, Memoria t. W002100.
Notes: Minimum tonnage: 3.5 million t @ 2.0% Cu, 17% Zn, 6% Pb, 68 g/t Ag, open at depth. Massive to semi-massive in two layers, separated by a few meters of ash tuff, 1150 m strike length, 70-250 m down-dip extent, 14.9 m thick (lower horizon), 10.8 m (upper horizon), open along strike and depth; banded layers; dissemination in footwall and hanging wall,stringer chalcopyrite-pyrite in footwall, but no stringer zone yet defined. SW end of deposit offset 150 m by NW-trending left-lateral fault.

References: Bucher, W.H., compiler, 1950, Geologic–tectonic map of the United States of Venezuela: Geological Society of America, scale 1:1,000,000.; Channer, D.M.D., and Anderson, P.F.N., 2000, Volcanogenic massive sulphide occurrences and potential in Venezuela, with emphasis on the Guayana Shield, in Sherlock, R.L., and Logan, M.A., eds., Volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits of Latin America: Geological Association of Canada Special Publication no. 2, p. 293–313.;
Notes: Massive sulfides, zoned with Cu-rich lower to Zn-Pb-rich upper.
